title: Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon
authors: Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
intervention:
Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package provided
community-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspected
malaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)
and diarrhoeal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
outcomes-bf:
Awareness, access and attitudes towards CHW
services among caregivers improved with intervention
outcomes-behavior:
Children living in intervention vs comparison
areas were significantly more likely to receive treatment
at a public health facility or through a CHW for fever  and diarrhoea

Appropriate treatment was significantly higher among children
in intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarial
treatment for fever , ACT
for fever , ORS for
diarrhoea and zinc for
diarrhoea

title: Evaluation of a social marketing intervention promoting oral rehydration salts in Burundi
authors: Kassegne S, Kays MB, Nzohabonayo J
population: Females of reproductive age/ 30 households from each of the 115 "collines" in Burundi
intervention: PSI led this Social marketing intervention to promote the use of ORASEL for children under five. Campaign included mass media promotion and community outreach
outcomes-bf: Positive changes in behavioral determinants associated with ORASEL use
outcomes-behavior: ORASEL use among caregivers at their children’s last diarrheal episode increased significantly from 20% in 2006 to 30% in 2007.
smbc: 5:Behavior Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Mixed methods,

title: National Scale-up of Zinc Promotion in Nepal: Results from a Post-project Population-based Survey
authors: Wang W, MacDonald VM, Paudel M, Banke KK
journal: Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2011, 29 (3): 207-217
population: Households/Households surveys with children under 6 years of age
intervention:
The Social Marketing Plus for Diarrhoeal Disease Control: Point of Use Water
Disinfection and Zinc Treatment (POUZN) project; Survey regarding knowledge and beliefs about zinc treatment after tha airing of a national mass-media campaign
outcomes-bf:
Over half (53.1%) of all
caregivers (n=3,550) interviewed had heard about zinc products; most (97.1%) of those who had heard of zinc knew that zinc should be used for the treatment of diarrhoea.
outcomes-behavior: At follow-up,  the majority (67.5%) of children (n=289), aged less than six years, with diarrhoea were treated with ORS, and 15.4% were treated with zinc. Children whose caregivers recalled the mass-media message that zinc should be used for 10 days and whose caregivers perceived that zinc is easy to obtain were more likely to be treated with zinc for 10 days, along with ORS
smbc: 5: Behavior, Theory, Customer orientation, Insight Mixed methods

title: Determinants of Use of Household-level Water Chlorination Products in Rural Kenya, 2003-2005
authors: DuBois AE, Crump JA, Keswick BH, Slutsker L, Quick RE, Vulule JM, Luby SP
journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 2010, 7 (10): 3842-3852
population: Users and non-user controls of a new household water treatment product regarding drinking water and socioeconomic factors from 10 Villages with 1,452 compounds
intervention: Use of socially marketed household water treatment systems: flocculent-disinfectant and sodium hypochlorite
outcomes-behavior: Reports of ever using the sodium hypochlorite solution ranged from 21% to 59%, while rates of use in the past 7 days ranged from 7% to 27%
smbc: 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Segmentation, Exchange, Method mix

title:
Shame or subsidy revisited: social mobilization for sanitation
in Orissa, India
authors:
Pattanayak SK,
Yang J,Dickinson KL, Poulos C, Patil SR, Mallick RK, Blitstein JL, 
Praharaj P
journal: Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2009,87:580–587
intervention: Intensive IEC campaign that used social marketing strategies and  community led total sanitation
outcomes-behavior:
Latrine ownership did not increase in control villages, but in treatment villages it rose from 6% to 32% in the overall sample,
from 5% to 36% in households below the poverty line  and from 7% to 26% in households above
the poverty line
smbc: 7: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Increasing equity of access to point-of-use water treatment products through social marketing and entrepreneurship: a case study in western Kenya
authors: Freeman MC, Quick RE, Abbott DP, Ogutu P, Rheingans R
population: 487 randomly selected households in eight communities served by the women’s groups
intervention:
Safe Water System is a simple, inexpensive, point-of-use (POU) household water quality intervention using: 1) locally produced sodium hypochlorite
solution for water treatment; 2) safe storage with containers
with a narrow mouth, tight fitting lid and tap; and 3) behaviour change communications; women’s groups in western Kenya were trained to
educate neighbours and sell health products to generate income (PSI)
outcomes-bf: Knowledge of water treatment products was high
outcomes-behavior: 20% (range 5–39%) of households in eight communities purchased and used chlorine, as confirmed by residual chlorine observed in stored water

title: Diarrhoea prevention in a high-risk rural Kenyan population through point-of-use chlorination, safe water storage, sanitation
authors: Garrett V, Ogutu P, Mabonga P, Ombeki S, Mwaki A, Aluoch G, Phelan M, Quick RE
population:
Comparison of
diarrhoea rates in 960 children aged <5 years in 556 households in 12 randomly selected
intervention villages and six randomly selected comparison villages during weekly home visits
over an 8-week period
intervention: Social Marketing to promote the Safe Water System (SWS) in collaboration with CARE Kenya's program to provide latrines and rainwater collection
outcomes-behavior:
Intervention households were also more likely to have residual chlorine in their stored water (43%of visits vs. 0%) and to possess a
latrine (49% of visits vs. 27%)
outcomes-health: On multivariate analysis, chlorinating stored water [relative risk (RR)0.44, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.28–0.69], latrine presence (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.54–0.92), rainwater use (RR 0.70, 95% CI 0.52–0.95), and living in an intervention village (RR 0.31, 95%CI 0.23–0.41), were independently associated with lower diarrhoea risk

title: Bringing Safe Water to Remote Populations: An Evaluation of a Portable Point-of-Use Intervention in Rural Madagascar
authors: Ram PK, Kelsey E, R, Miarintsoa RR, Rakotomalala O, Dunston C, Quick RE
population: Respondents from 242 households in 4 villages were interviewed
intervention: Social marketing campaign to promote SWS and SurEau water disinfectant. Campaign used community based sales agents.
outcomes-bf: Respondents from 239 households (99%) had heard of Sûr’Eau, the SWS disinfectant
outcomes-behavior:
226 (95%) reported having ever used Sûr’Eau, and 166 (73%) reported current use. Current Sûr’Eau use was confirmed
in 54% of households.

title:
Sustained High Levels of Stored Drinking Water Treatment and Retention of Hand-Washing
Knowledge in Rural Kenyan Households following a Clinic-Based Intervention
authors: Parker AA, Stephenson R, Riley PL, Ombeki S, Komolleh C, Sibley L, Quick R
intervention:
Nurses in a maternal and child health clinic were
trained in household water chlorination with a locally available, social marketed product, and in
six steps of proper hand washing. Nurses initiated client education
sessions on the SWS, hand-washing techniques, and
diarrhoea prevention messages at the MCH clinic
outcomes-behavior:
After 2 weeks, free chlorine residuals were present in stored drinking water in 68 % of clients' homes and, 1 year later, in 71 % clients' homes. After 2 weeks, all six hand-washing steps were correctly demonstrated by 44 % of  clients, and by 34 % 1 year
later.

title: Acceptability of and Adherence to Dispersible Zinc Tablet in the Treatment of Acute Childhood Diarrhoea
authors: Nasrin D, Larson, CP, Sultana S, Khan, TU
journal: Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2005, 23 (3): 215-221
population: Children between the ages of 3 and 59 months and their caretakers
intervention: Distribution and sales of zinc tablets by a social marketing firm
outcomes-bf: The formulation was acceptable to children; 90.1% of 303 caretakers perceived that the tablets were equally or even more acceptable to their children compared to other medicines.
outcomes-behavior: Ninety-eight percent of the children received the standard dose of one tablet per day, 55.8% completed the full 10-day course of zinc treatment

title: Social marketing and motivational interviewing as community interventions for safe water behaviors: Follow-up surveys in Zambia
authors: Thevos AK, Olsen SJ, Kaona FAD, Tembo M, Quick RE
journal: International Quarterly of Community Health Education, 2002, 21 (1): 51-65
intervention: Volunteer community health promoters in experimental (social marketing + motivational interviewing) and comparison (social marketing only) groups trained in causes of diarrhea and prevention through use of Clorin and safe water storage by SFH/Zambia. Health promoters in experimental group additionally trained in MI techniques.  After training, promoters conducted weekly household visits to promote and sell Clorin.
outcomes-bf: At 3 mos FU, 68% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 80% in SM+MI group (p>0.05). At 16 mos FU, 80% of households in SM group knoew of correct disinfectant use vs. 89% in SM+MI group (p>0.05).
outcomes-behavior: At 3 mos FU in Ndola,48% of households in SM group storing water safely vs. 87% in SM+MI group (p<0.01).  At 16 mos FU in Kitwe, 63% of household in SM group stored water safely vs. 64% in SM+MI group (p>0.05).

title: Evidence of behaviour change following a hygiene promotion programme in Burkina Faso
authors: Curtis V, Kanki B, Cousens S, Diallo I, Kpozehouen, Sangare M, Nikiema M
journal: Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2001, 79 (6): 518-27
population:
Mothers of
children aged 0–35 months, older sisters, maids, and school-aged children
intervention: Social marketing campaign involving house-to-house visits, performance of plays, and school curriculum
outcomes-behavior:
Safe
disposal of children’s stools changed little between 1995 and 1998 (80% pre-intervention, 84% postintervention);
hand-washing with soap after cleaning a child’s bottom rose from 13% to 31% and the proportion of
mothers who washed their hands with soap after using the latrine increased from 1% to 17%.
smbc: 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Challenges in Implementing a Point-of-Use Water Quality Intervention in Rural Kenya
authors: Makutsa P, Nzaku K, Ogutu P, Barasa P, Ombeki S, Mwaki A, Quick RE
intervention: Behavior change campaign to promote use of Safe Water System included advertising tools such as posters and brochures, as well as puppet shows , skits, and public demonstrations
outcomes-behavior: The project has resulted in adoption rates of 33.5% for chemical water treatment and 18.5% for clay pots modified for safe water storage.
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, insight, Exchange, Competition, Method mix

title: Collaboration, Cholera, and Cyclones: A Project to Improve Point-of-Use Water Quality in Madagascar
authors: Dunston C, McAfee D, Kaiser R, Rakotoarison D, Rambeloson L, Hoang AT, Quick RE
population:
CARE evaluated
the program’s impact in Mahavita
through baseline
and follow-up surveys of a random
sample of 375 households
in 15 neighborhoods
intervention: CARE contracted PSI to socially market the Safe Water System; Campaign to increase sales of SurEau water treatment
outcomes-behavior:
The utilization rate of Sûr’Eau in Mahavita households was 11.2% after 6 months. Utilization
in neighborhoods in the last stage of the community mobilization process was 19.7%, compared with 8.4% in those at an earlier stage (P=.01). Median free chlorine residuals in stored water were found to be 0.23mg/L in households using Sûr’ Eau, compared with 0.1 mg/L in households not using the product
(P=.005).
smbc: 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Methods mix

title: Analysis of different communication channels for promoting hygiene behavior
location: Six sub-districts in Khon Kaen province, Thailand
population: Households from selected villages and random selection of schools - study used questionnaires and FGD
intervention: Social marketing campaign to improve hand and dish-washing practices. Campaign involved both a variety of media outlets as well as village-level health workers
outcomes-bf: Strong correlation between number of communication channels remembered by respondents and knowledge.
outcomes-behavior: No significant improvements in behaviors outside of school children
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation,  Mixed Methods

title: Measuring the effect of a hygiene behaviour intervention by behaviour and diarrhoeal disease
journal: Transactions of the Royal Socity of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, 1996, 90 (4): 366-371
intervention:
A social marketing-based hygiene improvement campaign to promote hand washing, especially before feeding a baby, cooking, eating, and
after defaecation or cleaning a baby’s bottom, and dish washing immediately after eating
outcomes-behavior: There was a significant improvement in both behaviors in intervention versus control communities
outcomes-health:
Diarrhoea was less common in young children from the intervention villages, with 11 villages having lower incidence rates of diarrhoea
than 5 control villages; overall this amounted to a 39% reduction.
smbc: 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Exchange, Insight, Segmentation, Methods Mix
